I think this calendar doesn't account for the 3 years + 3 seasons time between halvings so far. When 2 week intervals with rising hashrate outnumber those with falling hashrate, blocks come slightly faster than every 10 minutes on average because difficulty adjustment is discontinuous
NOV 2012 July 2016 May 2020. At this rate of 3 years and 9-10 months we may get the first sliding halving of Late 2031 instead of 2032. Like March 2024. Jan 2028. Then Late 2031.
If it is off by a few months per four year cycle, we likely see this cumulative effect add up so it ends in 2130s

Balance on exchanges
March 2020: 3.1M coins
March 2024: 1.9M coins

i don't know how much that exchange reserve affects price but if it's an accurate relfection of real supply then we're going to see the monster of all bullruns... like shit that hasn't been seen since the very early days
Coins not on exchanges are less likely to be sold

are they? Maybe. But consider that coins on exchange are of two types: coins being actively traded, and coins being held as custody by people not smart enough to use their own key. As understanding of self custody improves one would assume the second group would shrink compared to the first.

So thinking forward let's say bitocin goes to 500k and a ton of OG hodlers take some profit by sending to exchange. Those coins are moved in, sold, and moved out, for a net 0 change to coins on exchange.

So I am not convinced that "coins ready to be sold" is the cohort that is leaving the exchanges in the largest number.

So some truth to what you're saying? Yes, sure. But how much? Likely the change in actual supply is less than the change in coins held on exchange

Bitcoin's price follows Amara's Law

Amara's Law is an observation made by futurologist Roy Amara, stating that people tend to overestimate the short-term impact of new technologies while underestimating their long-term effects. This law serves as a reminder to consider the broader context and timeline when predicting technological advancements.
